column1: ap < 06:00|"nearly six"|"I was five years old
column3: when Nelson Mandela was released from prison. I remember seeing it on TV and everyone being happy. I didn’t know why we were happy
column4: just that we were. I was aware of the fact that there was a thing called apartheid and it was ending and that was a big deal
column5: but I didn’t understand the intricacies of it."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o’clock"|"That carless Sunday we made our circuit of churches
column4: at white church. When we walked out of Rosebank Union it was dark and we were alone. It had been an endless day of minibuses from mixed church to black church to white church
column5: and I was exhausted. It was nine o’clock at least. In those days
column6: with all the violence and riots going on
column7: you did not want to be out that late at night. We were standing at the corner of Jellicoe Avenue and Oxford Road
column8: right in the heart of Johannesburg’s wealthy
column10: and there were no minibuses. The streets were empty."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: ap 04:30|"half past four"|"Where South Africa’s white countryside was lush and irrigated and green
column2: the black lands were overpopulated and overgrazed
column3: the soil depleted and eroding. Other than the menial wages sent home from the cities
column4: families scraped by with little beyond subsistence-level farming. My mother’s aunt hadn’t taken her in out of charity. She was there to work. “I was one of the cows
column6: “one of the oxen.” She and her cousins were up at half past four
column7: plowing fields and herding animals before the sun baked the soil as hard as cement and made it too hot to be anywhere but in the shade."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: ap < 06:00|"nearly six"|"Perhaps even more amazing is the fact that my mother started her little project
column3: at a time when she could not have known that apartheid would end. There was no reason to think it would end; it had seen generations come and go. I was nearly six when Mandela was released
column5: yet she was preparing me to live a life of freedom long before we knew freedom would exist. A hard life in the township or a trip to the colored orphanage were the far more likely options on the table. But we never lived that way. We only moved forward and we always moved fast
column6: and by the time the law and everyone else came around we were already miles down the road
column7: flying across the freeway in a bright-orange
column8: piece-of-shit Volkswagen with the windows down and Jimmy Swaggart praising Jesus at the top of his lungs."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column3: but I plucked up the courage to ask Zaheera for her phone number
column4: which was a big deal back then because it wasn’t like cellphone numbers where everybody has everyone’s number for texting and everything. This was the landline. To her house. Where her parents might answer. We were talking one afternoon at school and I asked
column5: “Can I get your phone number? Maybe I can call you and we can talk at home sometime.” She said yes
column6: and my mind exploded. What???!!!! A girl is giving me her phone number???!!! This is insane!!! What do I do??!! I was so nervous. I’ll never forget her telling me the digits one by one as I wrote them down
column7: trying to keep my hand from shaking. We said goodbye and went our separate ways to class
column10: Trevor. Play it cool. Don’t call her right away. I called her that night. At seven. She’d given me her number at two. That was me being cool. Dude
column11: don’t call her at five. That’s too obvious. Call her at seven."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"Our first gig was a New Year’s Eve party the summer we graduated from Sandringham. Bongani and I took my tower
column3: and all the cables and the keyboard and the mouse. We loaded everything up in a minibus and brought it over to Alex. We took over the street in front of his house
column4: ran the electricity out of his place
column8: and people came. It was explosive. By midnight the whole street was packed from one end to the other. Ours was the biggest New Year’s Eve party in Alexandra that year
column9: and to have the biggest party in Alexandra is no joke. All night
column11: people kept coming. The word spread: “There’s a light-skinned guy who plays music on a computer. You’ve never seen anything like it.” I DJ’d by myself until dawn. By then me and my friends were so drunk and exhausted that we passed out on the lawn outside Bongani’s house. The party was so big it made our reputation in the hood
column12: instantly. Pretty soon we were getting booked all over."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: 07:00|"seven a.m."|"The tricky thing about the hood is that you’re always working
column4: and you feel like something’s happening
column5: but really nothing’s happening at all. I was out there every day from seven a.m. to seven p.m.
column6: and every day it was: How do we turn ten rand into twenty? How do we turn twenty into fifty? How do I turn fifty into a hundred? At the end of the day we’d spend it on food and maybe some beers
column7: and then we’d go home and come back and it was: How do we turn ten into twenty? How do we turn twenty into fifty? It was a whole day’s work to flip that money. You had to be walking
column9: be thinking. You had to get to a guy
column11: meet a guy. There were many days we’d end up back at zero
column12: but I always felt like I’d been very productive."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: ~ 01:00|"around one in the morning"|"We took a minibus over to Diepkloof the night of the dance
column4: and Hitler. Hector won the competition. Then G was caught kissing one of their girls
column5: and it turned into a fight and everything broke down. On our way back to Alex
column7: as we were pulling out of Diepkloof to get on the freeway
column8: some cops pulled our minibus over. They made everyone get out and they searched it. We were standing outside
column10: when one of the cops came back."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"The garage gradually took over our lives. I’d get out of school and walk the five kilometers from Maryvale to the workshop. I’d sit for hours and try to do my homework with the machines and repairs going on around me. Inevitably Abel would get behind schedule on a car
column2: and since he was our ride
column3: we’d have to wait for him to finish before we could go home. It started out as “We’re running late. Go nap in a car
column4: and we’ll tell you when we’re leaving.” I’d crawl in the backseat of some sedan
column5: they’d wake me up at midnight
column6: and we’d drive all the way back out to Eden Park and crash. Then pretty soon it was “We’re running late. Go sleep in a car
column7: and we’ll wake you for school in the morning.” We started sleeping at the garage. At first it was one or two nights a week
column8: then three or four. Then my mom sold the house and put that money into the business as well. She went all in. She gave up everything for him."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: ~ 10:00|"around ten a.m."|"Then one morning I was in bed around ten a.m. and my phone rang. It was on a Sunday. I know it was on a Sunday because everyone else in the family had gone to church and I
column3: had not. The days of endlessly schlepping back and forth to church were no longer my problem
column4: and I was lazily sleeping in. The irony of my life is that whenever church is involved is when shit goes wrong
column5: like getting kidnapped by violent minibus drivers. I’d always teased my mom about that
column8: what good has come of it?”"|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"

column1: ap < 00:55|"nearly five to one"|"At the time
column2: black South Africans outnumbered white South Africans nearly five to one
column3: yet we were divided into different tribes with different languages: Zulu
column11: and more. Long before apartheid existed these tribal factions clashed and warred with one another. Then white rule used that animosity to divide and conquer. All nonwhites were systematically classified into various groups and subgroups. Then these groups were given differing levels of rights and privileges in order to keep them at odds."|"Born a Crime"|"Trevor Noah"
